title: Prostate Cancer Screening and Treatment
content: Presents the roadmap for the best way to screen for, and treat, prostate cancer. Discusses the “mass screening” controversy and all the risks involved with treatment. Also discusses our evolving understanding of cancer and the most exciting areas of research to come.

Discusses the evolving understanding of cancer and the most exciting areas of research to come. Discusses the history of prostate surgery, and the risks involved with treatment. content: Discusses the pros and cons of GLP-1 weight loss drugs and metformin as a geroprotective agent.

title: Prostate Surgery and Risks
content: It’s hard to access the prostate, it’s buried within the unique anatomy of the pelvis. In 1904, the first radical prostatectomy was performed using a perineal approach. This approach is safer from a blood loss perspective but it is not as good at removing all the cancer. For blood loss, it's important to understand where the veins are and control them by suturing them before they start bleeding. For retaining potency, it's crucial to work with anatomists and listen to patients. About 4% of cases, on average, have urinary leakage, more common in women and older men. For a 50 year old man, over 90% will regain function after surgery. But erectile dysfunction is an age-related dysfunction, so the older the patient the higher the chance of not fully regaining function.

title: Screening for Prostate Cancer
content: Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is a protein made by the prostate and its function is to liquefy semen. PSA is used as a tool to screen for prostate cancer by checking the values of the PSA in the blood. The bigger the prostate, the more PSA leaks into the blood. The older the person, generally the more PSA in blood. An infection or cancer in the prostate can make the PSA rise. Age-adjusted PSA levels are used to determine normal levels. However, no PSA number, no matter how low, guarantees that you don’t have cancer. Higher than normal levels are cause for more workup.

title: Biopsies and MRI in Prostate Cancer Diagnosis
content: A prostate biopsy is a procedure to remove samples of suspicious tissue from the prostate to test for cancer. Risks involved with biopsies include bleeding after the procedure and a small percentage of patients getting an infection. Before deciding on a biopsy, it's recommended to get a PHI or 4K score and if abnormal, get an MRI. If there’s an abnormality on the MRI, a biopsy is recommended. You should do the suspicious lesion plus doing a sextant biopsy. If the MRI is a false negative, the PSA density is looked at more closely. If PSA density if high, a biopsy is recommended.

title: Gleason Grading System
content: The Gleason grading system is a way to measure the aggressiveness of a cancer when looking at samples from a biopsy. In the beginning, you would get a Gleason sum: What’s the score of most prevalent abnormality on the view of the tumor (rated 1-5), What’s the score of the second most common, kind of glandular architecture (rated 1-5). You add those two scores together to get the Gleason sum. Now, it’s evolved to the Gleason grade group. There are some subtle differences in the Gleason sum that actually have real big differences for what the patient’s outcomes would be. In 2014/2015, a better way to transmit this Gleason information to patients and to internits in a way they can understand was created.

title: Testosterone, DHT and the Prostate Cancer Controversy
content: Men make a hormone called testosterone. Testosterone is converted via and enzyme called 5-alpha reductase into a very similar molecule called dihydrotestosterone (DHT). DHT is more potent than testosterone. DHT drives hair loss and enlarges the prostate. Medication (5-alpha-reductase inhibitors) used to reduce DHT: Proscar (finasteride) at five milligrams is taken to reduce prostate size, Propecia (finasteride) is one milligram is taken to reduce hair loss. Relationship between 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors and prostate cancer. The Prostate Cancer Prevention Trial showed that lowering DHT could reduce the risk of prostate cancer. But one of the problems was that there was increased detection of more aggressive cancers in men taking the drug to lower DHT.

title: The Decipher Test
content: GenomeDx product that’s very good at telling the aggressiveness of prostate cancer. Almost like a genomic Gleason score. Low androgen tumors vs high androgen tumors. Using the GenomeDx data, it has been shown that these low androgen output tumors are the most aggressive tumors. Very high androgen tumors are also aggressive, but they’re exquisitely sensitive to androgen deprivation, which is one of the mainstays of treatment for metastatic prostate cancer. Low androgen output tumors are not because they are not dependent on it for fuel.

title: The Metabolism of the Prostate
content: Do the mitochondria in the prostate cancer follow the Warburg effect? In other words, do they favor anaerobic metabolism over oxidative phosphorylation? There is not a lot known about the metabolic environment of the prostate. However, there is progress being made in this space. There is a lot of really interesting data looking at the sirtuin pathways through mitochondria regulating the hormonal dependency or hormonal regulation of prostate cancer.

title: The Most Exciting Areas of Research in Prostate Cancer
content: The most exciting stuff in urologic oncology is really moving beyond these prognostic biomarkers to predictive biomarkers you can pick up in the DNA of a tumor or the DNA of a patient. Particularly BRCA1, BRCA2, ATM loss. If you look in the tumors of men with metastatic castrate-resistant prostate cancer, depending on where you look, over one third of the tumors, the cells will have mutations in these pathways, which makes them incredibly sensitive to PARP inhibition, so that’s a huge game changer.

title: Benign Issues Involving the Prostate: Pelvic Pain, Infections and Treatments
content: Chronic pelvic pain covers common conditions like Nonbacterial prostatitis (inflammation in prostate, no infection), Interstitial cystitis. Prostatitis can be caused by an infection, or just inflammation. This falls into the bucket of “chronic pelvic pain”. Not so sure what causes it other than constipation. For deep-seated infections in their prostate, you can actually directly inject antibiotics into the prostate. The typical nidus for this persistent infection is actually the seminal vesicle, which is attached to the prostate. So they will to a transrectal injection directly into the seminal vesicle.

title: Male Contraceptives
content: Anything coming soon outside of a vasectomy? Some stuff that can block testosterone in the testicle, some coming soon. Vasectomies are a safe procedure for sure (maybe freeze some sperm first). Easy to reverse? Over 90% are reversible with a good procedure.
